positive_examples: This category has a fixed essence that makes it what it is.
There's a fundamental nature that all members of this group share.
You either are or aren't X - there's no in-between.
The defining property is inherent and unchangeable.
This is what X really is at its core, regardless of surface variation.
negative_examples: Categories are useful constructs with fuzzy boundaries.
Group membership is often a matter of degree.
Properties can change based on context and development.
Classification is useful but shouldn't be reified.
Things can share features without having a common essence.
training_hints.disambiguation: Detects essentialist thinking versus constructivist/contextual views. Key markers: fixed essence, fundamental nature, really is, inherent, either/or.

definition: A signal indicating belief that categories have underlying fixed essences defining their nature.
